Additional forms: Also Gondi_Traskānā, Gondi_Muask-to cut (meat), carve (ask-is pl. action ofacc-)

Notes: Hardly a proper PGn root (all the forms could have easily been borrowed from Telugu).
The Kui-Kuwi forms are probably borrowed from Telugu, because geminated-ḍḍ-is not usually reconstructed for PGn.

The root was heavily used with posessive prefixes. The most frequent form is*yay-'my mother'. In some dialects this form became generalized, with the following shift of meaning: 'my mother' > 'mother in general', 'mother' > 'woman'. A new form, based on the 1st person pl. pronoun (Gondimāy-, Kuwimāya) resulted from the loss of initialy-and the secondary merger of the simple and the prefixed forms.
The form*māy-means 'my mother', while*mīy-is 'your mother'
Initial*ē-may be caused by an old pronominal prefix of the 1st person; unfortunately, the lone isolated Koya form does not allow to make any definite conclusions.

This deictic base had the following declineable forms in PGn:*aw-ant_[-u](whence Gondi*ōn-R, Kondavānr_uwith a metathese, etc.) 'that man', plural*aw-ar[-u]'those men'; fem.*a-d-i(PK*ādiby analogy with masculine forms), plural*a-v-i. Also reconstructed for the PGn level is*a-c-'that many, that much' (PG, PPM, PK);*a-tal'that side' (Konda, PK, possibly Gondi);*a-mb-/*a-b-'there' (Konda, PPM, PK).  An enormous number of derivatives has been formed independently in different languages (which is characteristic of all deictic bases).

Although the resonant here is most certainly a plain dental-l-, it becomes retroflex in Konda (cf. especially such derivative forms asaṛpa-). This is not quite clear; maybe it is a general feature of *-l- before the causative marker. Unfortunately, this is the only example of such a cluster (in a few other cases we have no BB forms with-ṛ-, which are diagnostic).
Bisyllabic root.
The Gondi semantic shift to 'father' can be connected with the "extra" suffix-l.
The Proto-Gondwan character of this root is dubious, especially since the regular reflex of PDR*-mb-in Gondi is-m-. Some, or all of the forms, could have been re-borrowed from Telugu.
In some dialects only encountered with the pronominal prefixt-.
Koyayeŋgeshould be considered as a 1st person possessive form ('my..')
In Kui a shift of meaning: 'father' > 'son' (such a shift happens in SDR as well, when the word for 'father' is applied to children as term of endearment).

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Trmaipōmy father;mī-āpōthy father; Gondi_Ko (Su.)tappe(his, her) father

Notes: Possibly more than one root involved; unfortunately, Gondwan reflexes of former bisyllabic verbal bases with a vocalic anlaut are quite poorly studied.

Retroflex articulation in Betul and Mandla is strange and probably erroneous. Various epenthetic vowels in different dialects are due to developments*arjil>*arijl>*arijVl, on one side, and*arjil>*arVjil>*arVjl>*arVjVl, on the other.
Bisyllabic root.

Additional forms: Also caus. Gondi_Trarhuttānā, Gondi_Pharahtānā,arsahtānā, Gondi_Muarih-/arh-, Gondi_Sarah-, Gondi_A (SR)arusānāto cause to fall; Gondi_Korāl-to fall (< Telugu)

Notes: The root was used only with the suffix*-k-(assimilated to the voiced*-r_-after reduction in Konda and PK).
Causative type of conjugation in PGn.
Vowel length in Gondi is not quite clear, maybe expressive (such a lengthening does happen sometimes in relation terms).

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Maavval(pl.avvasku) mother; Gondi_Lavālmother; Gondi_Trmaiwalmy mother (lit. our mother);mīwalthy mother (lit. your mother);awhāṛīmother, dam of man or beast; Gondi_Phavhā̆rīid. (for-harisee 2357)

Notes: The intransitive form is*avi-; the opposite transitive one is*av-k-.

Notes on correspondences: In PK possibly*-aṛ->*-āṛ-(or only in Kui? or only in the anlaut position in Kui? Debatable.)

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Ph caus.ārsahtānā; Gondi_Mu caus.ārih-; Gondi_S caus.ārcah-

Notes: In most dialects*berāl->*berel-through assimilation.

Notes on correspondences: PGn*-ṛ> Konda-l(-ṛin some dialects). In some Kui-Kuwi dialects the plural form has been generalised.

Notes: Bisyllabic root. In Konda and PPM it was used with a suffix: *āñd_ur-ka > *ānd_r-ka > *ānd_-ga, *ānd_-i-ka. In PK reduction of the second syllable led to a general simplification of the cluster.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Ko (T)āp-to make stop; Gondi_Ko (Su)āŋ-to stop (intr.);āp-id. (tr.)

Notes: The word was frequently used apluralia tantum, whence PPM and PG*ārku<*ārg-ku(cf. also Kuiārka).
It is hard to say whether in PK-k-was lost for phonetical or morphological reasons. If nasalisation in some Kuwi dialects is not secondary (bā̃vli), it may be a trace of an old nasalised velar.
The actual PGn form is*badk-, since the root was regularly used with the plural action suffix.

The exact nature of the inlaut cluster (phoneme?) is hard to determine: PK and PPM show*-r-, Konda speaks in favor of*-ṛ-, while Gondi gives several variants (*-y-,*-r-,*-l-; one dialect even has a unique*-ḷ-).
Causative conjugation in PGn (which explains voiceless reflexes everywhere).

Meaning: to beat, fight, strike with hammer

Notes: PPMj-is not quite clear. It can only be explained through assimilation (*sāc->*cāc-)  and then (!) dissimilation (*cāc->jāc-). The root itself had a velar suffix in its intransitive form (*sā-ŋ-) and a palatal causative suffix (*sā-c-).

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Tr, Gondi_A (SR)sāngānāto spread as a creeper; Gondi_Ma caus.āʔ-; Gondi_Koāh-to stretch out
Notes: The Adilabad form shows an irregular c-; Telugu influence?
The PK form is probably borrowed from Telugu, since PGn *-lk- > PK *-k- is strange.

Burrow & Emeneau put this root together with*jiRk-, but this is impossible. Not only the resonant is different, but alsoh-in Gondi_A and Gondi_Tr hardly can be traced back to*j-. More probable is the reconstruction*c-or*s-with a usual mix-up before*-l-.
Used mostly with suffixes.
Gondi_Mu is irregular (*hīkaṛwould be expected), probably re-borrowed from another dialect.
The exact relationship of this root with PK*crī-'to rot, decay' and PGn*sī-'pus, snot' (DEDR 1606) is yet to be defined.
Assimilation in PK (*sot_->*soc->*sos->*soh-) and in PG (otherwise*sot-would be expected).

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Trsohalē-jāṭāthe kōnch or cow-itch, Mucuna pruriens; Gondi_A (Su.)coh-,cohk-to itch
Also Gondi_Mu caus.hunjih-; Gondi_Muhuskaṛsleep; Gondi_Elwinhuskār, Gondi_Mauskaṛ,uskanḍid.

Notes: Gondi_Maur̨ve tallahasu-probably due to specific accent/reduction reasons.

Meaning: a blow with the hand, slap

Notes: It is unclear if Gondi_Sceppabelongs here or is a boroowing.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Chd caus.huṛsutānāto show; Gondi_Whūṛsahtānāto reveal; Gondi_Ph, Gondi_Wsūrālblind
Notes: The formhupsānāis probably borrowed from Telugu.
Vowel length in PK (Kui, exactly) is unclear, although in derivatives short -a- is also met.

The initial cluster was probably preserved in PK (although the exact phonetic character is doubtful). However, the form was reinterpreted asdye+ʔoli, i.e. the old root auslaut was confounded with a derivative suffix. The Konda form dates back to an old plural form (sōŋa<*jol-ŋa).
It seems that*ḍog-meant 'lizard', while its derivative*ḍog-ḍ-meant 'chameleon'; the latter is seen in Gondi_Trḍoggaland PK.
Kui*-ṛ-unclear.
The PK form may be borrowed from Telugudumārumu, which makes the comparison less trustworthy. In any case, vowel length in PK is secondary, probably compensatory (from*dumb-aru).
The change*-m->-b-in some dialects is probably due to assimilation. However, initial retroflex inḍubais probably misspelled.

Various assimilations, progressive as well as regressive, tend to obscure the root's consonantism. The formdupaby itself is only fixed in Konda by Burrow and Bhattacharya and in Kuwi_Isr, but it is the different types of assimilation that give away the original root structure.
In DED PPM and PK forms are erroneously compared with SDR*cāy-'to incline'; this is impossible because of the initial consonant.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Tr caus.rehtānā,ragstānāto cause to descend

Notes: Bisyllabic root.

Most of the seeming irregularities in this root's reflexation are the result of its joining with the root*vā-'to come' (*ey-v-). This form is seen in Gondi*ev-(and not*ey-) and PK*ey-v-. In PPM the old suffixal form*ey-k(probably a nominal derivative) was also used only withvā-. Kondaī-is irregular as well; maybe developed from*eyv-.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Wāwsahtānāto dispatch; Gondi_Muavh-/avih-to make to reach, bring, obtain

Notes: PK*eŋg-is secondary (formed as an anti-causative for*ek-), since it is not supported by any external data.
Bisyllabic root.
External data makes us regard-umhere as part of the root.
Whether we should rely on Gondi_FH and reconstruct an initial*y-or not, is highly questionable.

The exact velar is unknown: we either have a causative stem in Gondi (in which case the reconstruction should be*erg-) or a reinterpreted "non-causative" stem in PK (in which case we should have*erk-).
Bisyllabic root.

The root has an old suffixal-l-which is also seen in several other cases. It may be bisyllabic, but this is hard to prove. The causative form ('to winnow') was*ed_-l-c-> Kondaer_lis-, PK*ēRs-(original alveolar phoneme preserved because of*-l-; without it*eh-would be expected). PPM*zēc-> Pengojēc-has NOTHING! NOTHING! to do with this!!!
The formēt-goes back to*ēn-t-; however, Gondi_Lerpānāis probably not related.

Additional forms: Simple form in all dialectsēnd-to dance

Notes: The origins of PK-n-are not quite clear. Perhaps it results from*gaḍ-nḍiwith a metathese.
Bisyllabic root.
Forms in Gondi_W and Gondi_Ph are probably re-borrowed from some Indo-Arian dialect. The final-min Gondi_S is archaic, as shown by external data.
The root often contaminates with*kaṭ-'hard'.

Meaning: a k. of bird of prey
Notes: Since the form is only present in a single Gondi dialect, vowel length in PGn cannot be determined for certain.

There were actually several 'hook'-roots in PGn (see also*kōnḍ-; one should also probably reconstruct*kok-, cf. Gondikokkihoe, etc.), and naturally they all hopeleslly contaminated with each other. That is why we have Konda and PK*k-.
In Gondi irregular*k-.
A "weak cluster" in PGn.
External data shows *g- to be primary.
The root often contaminated with*kūḍ-'a k. of cage'.
The declineable forms in PGn are analogical to those formed from*a-(*iwanr_u'this man', etc.).

The original quality of the vowel has been preserved in Gondi_S (īn<*iv-n) and Gondi_Ch, which alone of all dialects has preserved some traces of-v-in its former position:iyel<*iv-l<*iv-nR. In most other dialects vowel quality has been modified, and some preserved the original-v-by means of a metathese.
Bisyllabic root.
See also PG*ir-vurtwo (masc.) Bisyllabic root.

Additional forms: Most dialects haveranḍ; Also Gondi_Tr, Gondi_Phrahk rahktwo each; Gondi_W, Gondi_Chranṭeboth, pair; Gondi_Trrancētwo or so

Notes: Forms with-kare actually plural forms.
Bisyllabic root; in Konda there has been a metathese (*usik->*isuk-) or an assimilation (*usik->*isik-).
Irregular PK*d-(although Winfield has bothd-andḍ-in Kui). Gondi and Konda show an old suffix*-k-.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Tr, Gondi_Ph, Gondi_Chd fem.raiyā; Gondi_L fem.leyā; Gondi_Ma fem.leya(pl.-sk); Gondi_Ko fem.lēydaṛ, (T)ledāḍi;Gondi_A (Su.) fem.ḍiyyā; Gondi_A (SR)lehmīyouth

Notes: Bisyllabic root and causative conjugation in PGn. The reflexation*ḍr-in PK is strange. Maybe it is possible to connect it with vowel length? (like, for example,*iṛi->*iṛi->*ṛi-, but*īṛi->*ʔṛi->*ḍri-).
Bisyllabic root, as seen on the basis of Kui-Kuwi and Pengo-Manda data.
The word had a PK derivative:*yēt_-ki'thirst' > PG*etk-(with secondary shortening), KondaēRki, PPM*ēski, PK*ēski.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Tryeh-gatāthe water gnat;yeha-kkorrthe diving grebe; Gondi_W, Gondi_Phetkthirst
Notes: The form 'thirst' should be reconstructed as*etk.
The exact ending of the word in PG is unclear.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Yēṛvir, Gondi_Mandērur, Gondi_Sēṛur, Gondi_Maēṛvurseven (masc.); Gondi_Tryēṛkseven each

Notes: The suffixes do not coincide in PK and PGn, but the root is obviously the same in both languages. In PK*kaṛay->*kṛay-, with*-y->*-ʔ-before the suffix.
No need to reconstruct an original bisyllabic root, since both*kar-nḍiand*kara-nḍiwould inevitably develop into Kuikrānḍi.
In Gondi_Mukaraṭiwe see the original-r-that has fallen out everywhere else in the cluster*-rnḍ-; this also led to vowel lengthening.
Bisyllabic root with irregularg-in PK.
Vowel lengthening in PPM unclear.
Gondi_Trkaṛāis irregular (*-l-would be expected). Maybe it doesn't belong here.
Bisyllabic root.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_A (SR)karivāla student;karusānāto teach; Gondi_Chdkarutānā, Gondi_Trkarehtānā, Gondi_Wkarahtānā, Gondi_Phkarrahtānā, Gondi_Mukarih-, Gondi_Makar̨ʔ-to teach

Notes: The word may be an old borrowing from IA (Skt.khaṇḍa-, whence aspiration in Gondi); then again, it may be a re-borrowing in Gondi.
Causative conjugation in Konda.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Trkanskstānāto send a dream (of god); Gondi_A (SR)kanjkānāto dream

Notes: The root is hardly bisyllabic, since there is no reduction in PK even with the derivative-ŋg-.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Phkarsahtānā, Gondi_Mukaṛih-to burn (tr.); Gondi_Mukaṛhafield for burning cultivation; Grigsonkarearea set apart for penda cultivation when left fallow for a term

Notes: Inlaut consonant unclear. Gondi points to*-d_-, while PK points to either a simple*ror an alveolar*r_. The inlaut consonant was probably alveolar, but either *r_v > Gondi *Rv or *d_v > PK *rv.
The root had a PGn derivative*kay-mul'bitter', whereas PKkambli, Mandakembel, etc.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_W, Gondi_Phkaitālbitter; Gondi_Trkehkebitter; Gondi_Mukaylebitter;kaymul burkabitter gourd; Gondi_Kokaymulbitter; Gondi_Lkayārraw, unripe; Gondi_Kokay-kaṭbile; Gondi_A (Su.)kaymūlbitterness

Notes: The form*kah-is secondary. The original situation was*kat-'to cut' and*kat-s->*kah-t-'to make to cut'; afterwards the forms became mixed.
Bisyllabic root.

An ultrashort epenthetical-e-seems to be present already on the PGn level (cf. Gondi vs. Kui forms). However, since there is no development*-e->*-ä-in PK, the root should be reconstructed as monosyllabic.

Meaning: to wait for; to watch out for
Notes: Gondi*-ē-is unclear. Maybe the root was reinterpreted as having a*-y-auslaut, in which case*kāy-p->*kē-p-.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Ko (Su.)kāp-to boil; Gondi_Mkāstahot; Gondi_Trkāsuhtānā, Gondi_Wkāsahtānā, Gondi_A (SR)kāsusānāto heat

Meaning: to carry on the shoulders; carrying yoke

Notes: The word had a causative conjugation in PGn (probably with the suffix*-p-).Hence the loss of  voice in Gondi, Konda and PPM (all these forms go back to*ked_-p->*ket_-; in PPM probably  a 'metathese of voice':*ked_->*get_-). The form*ket_-pi'door' goes back to PGn.
Bisyllabic root with first long vowel.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Mukism-to pinch; Gondi_Trkiccānāto pick bhājī, i.e. green leaves for salad

Notes: This extremely interesting root deserves a detailed commentary. The standard Dravidian root for ear    is*kev-(DEDR 1977, see PGn*kev-). The PK form for 'ear' thus stands isolated, the only    obvious decent comparison being Tuluceraḍu'ear', which is, moreover, dialectal and partly    irregular (palatalisation*k->c-in Tulu is a rare and uncertain thing). In [Burrow 1944]    both roots were compared with the Uralic forms for 'ear', especially Finnishkorva, etc., and  it   was concluded that both date back to PDR*kervi.This, however, seems highly unprobable.  Loss  of-r-everywhere but in Kui-Kuwi is an extremely strange and unique phenomenon,  especially   considering that not even a single trace of it was preserved in neither of the SDR  languages (where   we could at least expect some sort of gemination, like Tamil*cevviinstead  ofcevi).  Much  more probable is the connection of the PK form with the Dravidian words for  'ear-wax' (also  discussed by T. Burrow in [Burrow 1943]). The word should be reconstructed as*kiru-pīl,  'ear-excrements', and it has undergone radical transformations in most languages,  the most archaic  form being Tulukirmbilu. In most other languages the first syllable vowel was  assimilated to the inlaut combination of labialized sounds (Tamilkur_umpi, PG*koṛ-ŋel,  etc.); in Gondi we have the following development:*kirupīl>*korupīl> *koṛmbīl>*koṛŋīl>*koṛŋel.      The general situation is thus as follows. In Early Dravidian both forms (*kir-and*kev-) were co-existent, although the difference between them is unclear. Later the form*kir-was in most dialects completely replaced by the form*kev-and survived as an archaism only in PK (and in Tulu?). The original derivative*kirupīlsurvived, but in most dialects it was modified beyond recognition, especially since the origins of its derivation became lost.

The root is almost never used by itself, but always in conjunction with certain parts of body:*kir_l-+ 'leg' = ankle, etc. The correspondences are extremely complex, since it is very hard  to trace PK-rl-, PPM-eir-and Gondi-r-to a single proto-cluster. However, if we  assume this reconstruction, it would be quite possible to compare this form with SDR*kir_-'small' (DEDR 1594), especially since there is an appropriate parallel in Todakɨt_ eɫ̣f'ankle', literally 'small bone'. If we consider*-l-a suffix, the forms are easily explainable.
Inlaut-ɣ-assimilated in most dialects; however, it is usually preserved in the absolute auslaut (like Pengokoy) and seen in Kuikog-.
Several roots, hopeleslly contaminated already in PGn.
Gondi_Ma-rr-probably stands for-r̨-here.

Causative conjugation in PGn (so the inlaut consonant is unclear). This root (DEDR 2064) is preceded by DEDR 2063*koṭ-'to strike, beat, crush, thresh, etc.'; however, most of the forms in both entries are identic, and those that are not do not contradict each other. I suppose that this is actually a single root.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Akoṭelamallet; Gondi_Mu, Gondi_Makoṭeladrumstick; Gondi_Mukohk-to gore; Gondi_A (Su.)kohk-to grind into a paste, pound (in a mortar), beat stalks of millet, wheat, etc. on the ground so that the seeds fall down

Notes: The second component, seen in PPM and PK, is unclear: the usual suffix is simple *-ɣ-. Cf. such forms as Tamilkuṛ-āy. Konda-u-unclear; maybe due to back articulation of preceding/following velars.

Such forms as Kuikrōgaor Pengokṛō-could be regarded as pointing to an old bisyllabic root. However, I think that in this case metathese should be attributed to the tendency of cluster elimination, i.e. the structure*koṛv-has a tendency >*kṛo/v/-.

The Gondi_Lu_S form is more archaic, as is shown by external data. The form itself literally means 'curved arm' (*kōnd-+*kāy-) and has undergone modifications in Gondi dialects, primarily in the direction*-ndk->*-nadk->*-naŋk-, although the reason of*-o->-u-is not quite clear (probably due to surrounding back consonants).

This root, which encapsulates the self-naming of many Dravidian tribes, is extremely hard to  reconstruct. Besides the differences in vocalism, the inlaut consonant is very hard to determine;  especially since some of the etyma may be borrowed (thus,kūbiis not the self-naming of Konda  speakers themselves, but of Konda Dora dialect speakers). The root itself seems to be an old derivative of the word for 'mountain', in Tamilkō: this form points rather to a PGn variant*kov-.
The suffixed form*koṛg-(short vowel probably already in PGn) had an adjective meaning 'newly sprouted'.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Mukoṛk-ilanew leaf; Gondi_Makoṛtamonth of Bhadrā (Aug.-Sept.) when new paddy is worshipped; Gondi_A (Su.)koṛkēlātender, young
Notes: Original vowel length preserved in Gondi_Trkōṛs-.
Bisyllabic root.

Meaning: a tree the bark of which is used for making rope

Notes: Bisyllabic root?

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Ko caus. (T.)kup-, (Su.)kuppis-; many dialectskuttula stool to sit on

Notes: Bisyllabic root.
"Metathese of voice" in PPM and also in KondaguRi(BB) is probably due to contamination with*guṭ-'short'.
Bisyllabic root with reduction in Konda and PK (in Gondi >*kaṭl->*kāṛ-).
Bisyllabic root.
Causative conjugation in PPM and Konda.
The conjugation was causative, so devoicing is regular; in PPM we observe the almost regular "metathese of voice":*sēd_->*sēz->*zēc-.
Derivative of*sēd_-'to winnow', but on a very high level.
A "weak cluster". However, at least for this root it is confirmed by most dialects within Gondwan languages as well as in other ones.
Bisyllabic root.
Notes on correspondences: A rare type of bisyllabic nominal root with vocalic auslaut.

Notes: Bisyllabic root.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Wmargīnāto err;marangtālastray; Gondi_Mmārānāto lose; Gondi_A (Su.)marūm-to forget; Gondi_Trmakkānāto escape notice; Gondi_Wmakkānāto hide (intr.); Gondi_Trmakstānā,maksuhtānā, Gondi_Wmaksahtānā(tr.); Gondi_M

Notes: The form is reconstructed with *-d_k-, because *-t_k- > PK *-sk-.
Affricate suffix in PG, cf. Tulumalejji.
Bisyllabic root.
Unexplainedv-in Gondi; contamination with other roots is not excluded (see DED 5265).
All the forms go back to*mari-s-(causative suffix). Bisyllabic root.
Bisyllabic root.

Additional forms: Most dialects havemara; also Gondi_Mumaṛa naya kind of animal living on trees; Gondi_Komāṛ nēywild dog
Also Gondi_Ymarnḍeyaṛfemale cross-cousin; Gondi_A (Su.)marṇḍū(pl.-r) male cross-cousin

Notes: Kui-y-not quite clear; maybe it is a back-formation from*māŋga?

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Chmāmifather's sister, mother's brother's wife

Notes: PG*māh-<*māṭ-s-.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Hislopmitus-to apply (sacred mark); Gondi_A (Su.)miṭṭūs-to apply saffron powder on the forehead
Also Gondi_Trmehtānāto graze cattle;mehtārīgrazier, herd; Gondi_Mmehānāto graze; Gondi_A, Gondi_Y, Gondi_Dmēh-, Gondi_Mu, Gondi_Smeh-, Gondi_Mamēʔ-to grze (tr.)

Notes: Bisyllabic root.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Ma caus.miṛʔ-to turn over, invert

Notes: Causative conjugation in PGn (with*-s-).

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Amiṛc-to lighten; Gondi_A (Su.)miṛc-to glitter;miṛcvallightning; Gondi_Lu_Smeersheetattalightning; Gondi_Mamiṛŋgor̨spark; Gondi_A (Su.)minŋūṛspark

Notes: Strange vocalism in Konda and PPM (a unique case).
In PPM probably shortening by analogy with plural*min-k-<*mīn-k-.
External data shows *-ḍḍ- to be primary. Maybe in Maria *-uḍ- > *-uṭ-?
Used mostly with suffixes:*mud_-s-> PG*muhc-,*mud_-l-> Kondamur_li-,*mud_-k-> PPM*murg-, PK*musk-.

Additional forms: Also Gondi_Trmuccī, Gondi_Ph, Gondi_Mumuccea lid or cover; Gondi_Mamuccecover of pot, lid
Also Gondi_A (Su.)munḍāa wooden pole in the shape of Bhima;munḍēlpole

Notes: Bisyllabic root. In Gondi a progressive assimilation. In Kui*mrāl-would be expected. It is, however, not excluded that*-r-> PK*-ṛ-before*-l-(for example, because of dissimilation of two different dental resonants; the process is thus the opposite of the one in Gondi). In PPM only Pengo data is present, so the exact vocalism is unclear; however, since PG *koṛ-aɣ- > PPM*kṛɔy-, it is very much probable that the case here is similar.
Vocalism in Konda and PK is strange; probably a dissimilation in position between two labials.
PK form probably goes back to*muṛṇ-ŋ-. It is yet unclear if PGn*munj-is related here.

Notes: A very complicated root. PK form can go back to*nr_eʔ-<*ner_e-; PG form goes back to*nir_-n-. However, the status of Konda and Manda forms is unclear. Maybei-is a prefix (deictic base 'this'?), since loss of initialn-is impossible for both languages. In this case Kondainen<i-ner_(assimilation?), and Mandaineliŋ<*i-ner_-ŋ.
Bisyllabic root. In PK*neri->*nire->*nrē->*drē-.

Also Gondi_Tr, Gondi_W, Gondi_Phnihtānā, Gondi_A, Gondi_G, Gondi_Mu, Gondi_S, Gondi_Konih-, Gondi_Maniʔ-to fill (tr.)

Notes: In Gondi-m-by analogy with the plural forms.

The original form was preserved in PK. In other groups*noḷ-was used only with suffixes, so  PPM*noḷ-nj->*nḷo-nj->*ṛonj-; PG*noḷ-nj-k->*nḷo-s-k->*ḷosk-.  In Konda the formlo-(causative type, from*noḷp-) probably developed by analogy withlonz-<*noḷ-nj-. There is no need to suggest that the root was originally bisyllabic, especially since it is clearly monosyllabic in PK.

Burrow and Emeneau put this root together with*nūd_-'to grind' as a derivative, but this is  hardly possible, since PGN*nūd_-k-should give*nūt_-k-with KondanūRka, etc. In any  case, this 'derivative' should obviously be reconstructed on the PGn level and higher.
Most dialects havenūŋg
Also Hislopnur, Gondi_A (Su.)nūr(pl.nuhk) hundred
Bisyllabic root.
The form in Gondi hasa-, but it is only present in L., and the reflexes of*o-in L. are not quite certain.

The root is highly uncertain. It is supposedly bisyllabic; this is shown by initial*cṛ-in PK and Gondi_Lrawa<*srawa. However, both the initial and anlaut consonants are unclear. Gondi and Kuwi speak in favor of*s-, while Kui supposes*c-; the same goes for inlaut-r-(in Gondi and Kuwi) and-ṛ-(in Kui). Maybe the Kui form is dialectal or contaminated, although it is unclear what with.
In Gondi_Lu_S*sarVva>*srawa>rawa.
Bisyllabic root.

Initial*b-in both PPM and PK, as Burrow and Emeneau state, is due to re-borrowing of both items from local Oriya, where it has been in turn borrowed previously with an initialb-. Actually, one can speak rather of Oriya influence on the form than of a direct borrowing.
